Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Microbial detoxification of cellulosic biomass hydrolysates by anaerobic removal and recovery of aromatic compounds

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Daniel R. Noguera
Proposal Number: 1506820

A major challenge facing the production of biofuels from plant biomass is the presence of unwanted byproducts resulting from the conversion of the cellulosic portions of the biomass to fermentable sugars. These byproducts, primarily from the water soluble lignin fraction of the biomass, are toxic to the fermentation process, and reduce biofuel production yield. This project will investigate the use of bacteria to convert these byproducts into a single aromatic compound which can be recovered as a valued co-product in an engineered biological process without consuming the valuable sugars. The course of this research will also advance fundamental understanding on how related anaerobic microbial processes affect the natural carbon cycle. Other impacts of the project include educational activities related to mentoring high school, undergraduate, and graduate students on topics related to the research.

The overall goal of this proposed research is to study the potential of anaerobic bacteria to convert plant-derived aromatic compounds found in cellulosic biomass hydrolysates into a single phenolic compound that can be recovered as a valued co-product in a cellulosic biorefinery. The proposed approach takes advantage of anaerobic microbial degradation of aromatic compounds, and in particular, the metabolism of cultured members of the Rhodopseudomonas genus that are effective at consuming a large variety of aromatic compounds without utilizing the sugars needed for biofuel production. It is hypothesized that the aromatics present in the hydrolysates are degraded R. palustris through the benzoyl-CoA pathway. The proposed research will genetically engineer this organism to transform the large diversity of aromatics typically present in biomass hydrolysates to either benzoic acid or p-hydroxybenzoic acid, depending on the location of the mutation. The metabolic diversity of an existing Rhodopseudomonas collection will be tested to identify the best strains for detoxification of cellulosic hydrolysates. Experiments will be carried out with a mixture of the Rhodopseudomonas strains under phototrophic and denitrifying conditions, using both corn stover hydrolysates prepared with industrially relevant biomass loadings as well as variations of a synthetic medium that simulates the hydrolysate. The genetic and regulatory networks of anaerobic aromatic degradation in the best performing Rhodopseudomonas strains will be reconstructed, using RNA-Seq and genome re-sequencing. Once the strain has been engineered to promote the biotransformation of aromatics as benzoic acid, the rate processes for removal of aromatic compounds from cellulosic hydrolysates and the recovery of the benzoic acid co-product will be studied in bioreactor systems. Research outcomes will be used to enhance content for three courses in the Environmental Engineering program at the University of Wisconsin, Madison.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The production of renewable fuels from cellulosic biomass is an area of active research because it could help reduce societal dependence on fossil fuels. Currently, major bottlenecks exist for the cost-effective production of biofuels from cellulosic biomass. Specific challenges for microbial transformation of deconstructed biomass include reducing toxicity from high-concentration fermentation products, removing plant-derived inhibitors present in the biomass hydrolysates used for microbial biofuel production, and effectively fermenting pentoses. This project addressed the toxicity caused by plant-derived inhibitors present in hydrolysates, in particular the presence of inhibitory aromatic compounds.

Intellectual Merit: We demonstrated that the bacterium Rhodopseudomonas palustris can degrade aromatic compounds present in hydrolysates, without consuming the sugars, and therefore, hypothesized that R. palustris could be used as a pretreatment of hydrolysates before biofuel production by a fermenting culture. Bioreactor experiments with R. palustris under anaerobic conditions, using hydrolysates generated from corn stover, produced the interesting observation that R. palustris degraded certain aromatics present in the hydrolysates, even though it could not degrade those same aromatics when they were present as the sole carbon source in laboratory minimal media.

These results prompted us to ask whether we could adapt R. palustris strains to degrade syringic acid, one of the most inhibitory aromatics in hydrolysates, even though they are not known to utilize this aromatic as a sole carbon source. We developed an adaptation strategy in which we first grew R. palustris on medium containing syringic acid plus a combination of benzoic acid and para-hydroxybenzoic acid, which are aromatics known to be growth substrates for this microorganism. In each growth iteration, we reduced the amount of benzoic and para-hydroxybenzoic acids and increased the amount of syringic acid, until we obtained adapted strains capable of growing on syringic acid as the sole carbon source. One adapted strain was isolated (strain SA008.1.07) and further characterized.

R. palustris strain SA008.1.07 grew anaerobically on syringic acid as the sole carbon source, but could not grow aerobically on this aromatic substrate. The genome of this adapted strain was re-sequenced and compared with the genome of the parent strain. Four mutations were identified, but we were not able to demonstrate that any of these mutations conferred the ability to grow on syringic acid. A transcriptomic analysis was used to identify enzymes that were preferentially expressed when growing on syringic acid compared to growth on para-hydroxybenzoic acid or succinate. Surprisingly, this analysis suggested the involvement of the VanAB enzyme in anaerobic syringic acid degradation. VanAB is known to participate on degradation of the aromatic compound vanillic acid under aerobic conditions, and requires molecular oxygen as a substrate for breaking down the aromatic ring, so the participation of this enzyme in anaerobic syringic acid degradation was unexpected. Nevertheless, mutants with a deletion of VanAB lost the ability to degrade syringic acid, and when VanAB was re-introduced to the deletion mutant, syringic acid degradation was restored.

The discovery of VanAB participating in anaerobic syringic acid degradation may indicate that this family of enzymes may have a yet unexplored secondary activity related to degradation of aromatic compounds under anaerobic conditions. The results also suggest that a new pathway for anaerobic aromatic degradation may be present in R. palustris and related organisms.

Broader Impacts: this project contributed to the training of three PhD students, on postdoctoral researcher, five undergraduate students, and two high school students. As members of the research group, these students had opportunities to practice giving scientific presentations and engage in multidisciplinary research activities. Graduate students were engaged in educational activities by mentoring undergraduate and high school students, and as teaching assistants. The high school students used their training in the laboratory as the practicum requirement to obtain a certificate in biotechnology by the time they graduated from high school, as part of the Wisconsin Youth Apprenticeship Program.
